Document Sources.Sourced Statement: new data obtained by The Standard from Humboldt’s own relocation program show that the county’s homeless people were bused to San Francisco on four occasions between October and March.
Document Sources.Source Justification: new data obtained by The Standard from Humboldt’s own relocation program

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: According to the program’s website, social services staffers verify that those who use TAP will be received at their destination by a relative, friend, or appropriate agency.

“We were dismayed to learn that our small, rural county was among the top three destinations in the state where people experiencing homelessness were sent by the program,” states a draft of the letter to San Francisco Mayor London Breed that can be seen on the Humboldt County website.
Document Sources.Source Justification: a draft of the letter to San Francisco Mayor London Breed that can be seen on the Humboldt County website

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The aim isn’t to achieve a goal. It’s to get you out of our town, and it’s cheaper than arresting you,” Boden said. “The No. 1 answer to homelessness is to make them disappear. Then mayors write letters back and forth: ‘Stop sending your people here.’ Then it turns out they’re sending their people here. It shows the ridiculousness of us not trying to address why people are on the streets.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: a homeless advocate with the Western Regional Advocacy Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a homeless advocate with the Western Regional Advocacy Project

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Our TAP program works really well, and hopefully San Francisco can go back to more — not just dumping — but assisting and actually helping people get help,” Humboldt Supervisor Rex Bohn said at Tuesday’s board meeting.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Humboldt County officials voted Tuesday to send a letter raising the alarm about San Francisco’s plans to bus homeless people out of the city.
Los Angeles and Sacramento counties are the two other most popular California destinations, according to SF’s Department of Homelessness and Supportive Housing and the Human Services Agency.
Named Organization Sources.Name of Source: SF’s Department of Homelessness and Supportive Housing and the Human Services Agency
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: according to SF’s Department of Homelessness and Supportive Housing and the Human Services Agency

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: When asked for comment, the San Francisco mayor’s office said it had not received the letter.
